sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a combustion reaction
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change of combustion for methane, CH4(g), given that the balanced chemical equation for the combustion reaction is:

CH4(g) + 2 O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2 H2O(l)

Assume that all reactants and products are in their standard states and use the following standard enthalpy of formation values:

ΔHf(CH4(g)) = -74.81 kJ/mol
ΔHf(CO2(g)) = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf(H2O(l)) = -285.83 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change of combustion for methane, we can use the following equation:

ΔH_combustion = Σ ΔHf(products) - Σ ΔHf(reactants)

For the given reaction:

CH4(g) + 2 O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2 H2O(l)

The standard enthalpy of formation values are:

ΔHf(CH4(g)) = -74.81 kJ/mol
ΔHf(CO2(g)) = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf(H2O(l)) = -285.83 kJ/mol

We can now plug these values into the equation:

ΔH_combustion = [1 × (-393.5) + 2 × (-285.83)] - [1 × (-74.81) + 2 × 0]

Note that the standard enthalpy of formation for O2(g) is 0 kJ/mol since it is in its standard state.

ΔH_combustion = (-393.5 - 571.66) - (-74.81)

ΔH_combustion = -965.16 + 74.81

ΔH_combustion = -890.35 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change of combustion for methane, CH4(g), is -890.35 kJ/mol.
